start.title: The Apprentice of Croton
start.description: As a new apprentice, you'll discover the mathematical secrets that revolutionized our understanding of numbers, music, and geometry. Master the famous Pythagorean theorem through hands-on experiments and become one of the Mathematikoi—the keepers of mathematical wisdom.

S2_D1_FX_C0.heading: Narrator
S2_D1_FX_C0.body: The year is 520 BCE. In the bustling Greek colony of Croton, Italy, a school unlike any other has taken root, founded by the legendary thinker and lover of wisdom, Pythagoras. You are a new apprentice seeking knowledge, and to join the inner circle of Mathematikoi, you must first pass the initiations—your guide is waiting.

S4.S4_D1_FX_C1: Welcome, Apprentice. I’m Myia, daughter of Pythagoras. My father believes that to understand the world, we must first uncover its hidden language: numbers, because everything follows patterns—from the seasons to your heartbeat.
S4.S4_D2_FX_C1: By understanding these patterns, we understand the universe. Before we explore the shapes of the earth, let’s listen to the music of the cosmos. You’ll be amazed at what numbers can reveal.

S5_D0_FX_C9.title: The Virtual Monochord

help.heading: How to use this tool?
help.body:
• Click any proportion button to hear that musical interval.
  • Click Play Frequencies to continuously play both tones together.
  • Click the right string to hear the base frequency alone.
  • Drag the slider to adjust string length manually.

Tips

  • Try 2:1 for octave, 3:2 for fifth, 4:3 for fourth.
  • Simple ratios sound more harmonious than complex ones.
  • Watch how frequency values update as you adjust settings.

info.heading: About the Monochord
info.body:
Pythagoras used this simple instrument to discover that music follows mathematical laws.

How it Works

  • One string stretched over a resonating box.
  • Moving the bridge divides the string into different lengths.
  • Shorter lengths = higher pitches.
  • The ratio determines the musical interval.

Key Discoveries

  • 2:1 ratio = octave (same note, higher).
  • 3:2 ratio = perfect fifth (very harmonious).
  • 4:3 ratio = perfect fourth (also harmonious).
  • Simple ratios with small numbers sound better.

This became the foundation of music theory and showed that mathematics creates beauty.

S5_D0_FX_C9.virtualMonochordStrings: Virtual Monochord having two strings. The left string is the variable frequency string and the right string is the base frequency string.

S5.S5_D1_FX_C1: This is a monochord. It will be your first teacher. Pluck the string on the left
S5.S5_D2_FX_C1: Now, pluck the other string. It is exactly half the length—a ratio of 2:1.
S5.S5_D3_FX_C1: This is an octave. The same note, but higher. Press play to hear both the notes at the same time.
S5.S5_D4_FX_C1: Interesting, that the ratio of the two strings changes the feeling of the sound. Not all of the sounds are so nice, are they? Try the ratio of 3:2. That's another nice combination.
S5.S5_D5_FX_C1: You can now try these other mathematical ratios that were discovered by my father, like 4:3 or 5:4. Did you know that you could hear the beauty of mathematics?

S6.S6_D1_FX_C1: The perfect fifth—that 3:2 ratio—is so pleasing it shaped music for centuries. But numbers don’t stop there—my father learned from Egyptian priests that they can also measure shapes on the earth, which is called geometry, and I can even show you their shapes with these pebbles.

about.heading: About pebble mathematics
about.body:
Ancient Greeks used pebbles to understand number patterns before written mathematics existed.

Even and odd numbers:

  • Even numbers split into two equal groups
  • Odd numbers always have one left over
  • This creates symmetric vs asymmetric arrangements

Figurate numbers:

  • Triangular numbers: 1, 3, 6, 10, 15, 21...
  • Square numbers: 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36...
  • These numbers form perfect geometric shapes with pebbles

This hands-on method helped ancient mathematicians understand number properties we still use today.

help.heading: How to use this tool?
help.body:
• Use the slider to select how many pebbles to arrange
  • In the first step, watch how pebbles arrange in two rows
  • Even numbers make perfect rectangles with no leftover pebbles
  • Odd numbers always have one pebble left over
  • Try arranging pebbles into triangles and squares

Tips:

  • Try numbers like 9, 16, 25 to see perfect squares
  • Try numbers like 3, 6, 10, 15 to see perfect triangles
  • Notice how some numbers work for both shapes

S7.S7_D1_FX_C1: Let’s start with even and odd numbers. All even numbers can form a perfect rectangle in two rows. Odd numbers always have one left over. Try it with the slider!
S7.S7_D2_FX_C1: Some numbers are special—they can form perfect squares. Nine, for example, makes a square with 3 pebbles on each side. But 10 can’t. Try it yourself!
S7.S7_D3_FX_C1: Great! That’s why three times three is called 'three squared.'
S7.S7_D4_FX_C1: Now I will teach you the most sacred shape of my father. What is 1 + 2 + 3 + 4?
S7.S7_D5_FX_C1: That’s right! Use the slider to set the pebbles count to 10. Ten produces a shape like an equilateral triangle. Behold the Tetractys.
S7.S7_D6_FX_C1: The rows—one, two, three, four—add up to ten. My father loves this because it holds the musical ratios you just discovered. It also represents the building blocks of our universe: the point, the line, the plane, and the solid.
S7.S7_D7_FX_C1: This shows that math itself is harmonious—and that the universe is built from numbers. Which of these can form triangles?

S8.S8_D1_FX_C1: Now that you've seen how numbers have their own shapes, let me show you how my father discovered an even more powerful secret—how builders in Croton use a 12-knot rope to form a perfect right angle with sides of 3, 4, and 5 units, and how my father uncovered the universal law hidden in the squares of their sides that explains why it always works.

S9_D0_FX_C9.title: The Pythagorean Theorem Proofs

info.heading: About This Interactive
info.body: Explore three different ways to prove the Pythagorean theorem: using pebbles, water areas, and geometric dissection.

help.heading: How to Use
help.body: Follow Myia's guidance through each proof method. Interact with the pebbles, pour the water, and rearrange the triangles to see the theorem in action.

proof1Info.heading: About the Pebble Proof
proof1Info.body:
How to Use the Pebble Proof Tool

  • Select a Pythagorean triple (3-4-5, 6-8-10, or 5-12-13).
  • Click Calculate & Animate.
  • Watch pebbles from the red square (a2) and blue square (b2) fill the green square (c2).
  • Drag to move the view and scroll to zoom.

What You’re Seeing

The pebbles show the Pythagorean Theorem: a2 + b2 = c2. The two smaller squares always combine to exactly fill the largest square — just as the Ancient Greeks proved using pebbles.

proof2Info.heading: About the Pouring Proof
proof2Info.body:
How to Use the Pouring Proof Tool

  • Use sliders to set values of a and b.
  • Click Pour A to empty the blue square (a2) into the gray square.
  • Click Pour B to empty the red square (b2) into the gray square.
  • Scroll to zoom, drag to pan, and press Reset to try again.

What You’re Seeing

a2 + b2 = c2

Water from the two smaller squares fills the largest square, proving the Pythagorean Theorem.

Why Water? Pebbles only work with whole numbers, but water works for any value, making the proof more general.

proof3Info.heading: About the Dissection Proof
proof3Info.body:
How to Use the Dissection Proof Tool

  • Use sliders to adjust the lengths of a and b.
  • Click Rearrange to move the four identical right triangles.
  • First arrangement shows the tilted green square (c2).
  • Second arrangement shows the blue square (a2) and red square (b2).

What You’re Seeing

a2 + b2 = c2

The same four triangles can be arranged two ways: around the square on the hypotenuse (c2), or around the two leg squares (a2 and b2). Since the pieces and total area never change, it proves the Pythagorean Theorem.

Click on Animate proof button to move pebbles from square A and square B to square C to demonstrate that the number of pebbles in square C equals the total number of pebbles in square A and square B.

S9_D0_FX_C9.screenReaderValues: a equals {a}, b equals {b}, c equals {c} and therefore a squared equals {aSquared}, b squared equals {bSquared}, c squared equals {cSquared}
S9_D0_FX_C9.screenReaderSquaredValues: a squared equals {aSquared}, b squared equals {bSquared} and c squared equals {cSquared}
S9_D0_FX_C9.firstPosition: First position: Four identical right triangles are arranged around c squared square hypotenuse.
S9_D0_FX_C9.secondPosition: Second position: Four identical right triangles are arranged around the a squared square and b squared square legs. The total area stays the same, proving a squared plus b squared equals c squared.

S9.S9_D1_FX_C1: My father loves triangles. He found that rectangles can be described as two triangles, and these special triangles with a 90-degree angle are called right triangles.
S9.S9_D2_FX_C1: When we make squares from the sides of a right triangle, the pebbles in the smaller squares add up perfectly to form the square of the longest side—the hypotenuse—so we write it as a² + b² = c².
S9.S9_D3_FX_C1: Do you see? The pebbles in the two smaller squares perfectly equal the number in the largest one! Try this with another triangle.
S9.S9_D4_FX_C1: My father wanted to prove his theorem works for all right triangles, not just those with whole numbers. Watch how water reveals this universal truth.
S9.S9_D5_FX_C1: Each square’s area equals the square of its side length. The water’s volume perfectly represents that area—it can fill any shape, unlike pebbles that only work with whole numbers.
S9.S9_D6_FX_C1: Now pour the water from both smaller squares into the largest one. Watch carefully as the areas combine and fill it exactly!
S9.S9_D7_FX_C1: This proves the theorem’s true power—it works for every right triangle, no matter what numbers you choose.
S9.S9_D8_FX_C1: Here is the most elegant proof of all—it uses no numbers, no counting, just pure geometric reasoning that convinced even the greatest scholars.
S9.S9_D9_FX_C1: Look at these four identical right triangles arranged around the tilted green square. This green area represents c², the square of the hypotenuse.
S9.S9_D10_FX_C1: Now rearrange the same four triangles to the corners. They surround two separate squares—one blue square for a² and one orange square for b².
S9.S9_D11_FX_C1: The magic is that we used exactly the same pieces in both arrangements! Since the triangles occupy the same space, the remaining areas must be equal. You’ve just proven a² + b² = c² using pure logic and shapes.

info.heading: About This Interactive
info.body: We will apply the Pythagoras Theorem to solve the real world problems.

help.heading: How to Use
help.body: Follow the steps and what you have learnt into practice.

problem1Info.heading: The Ladder Problem
problem1Info.body:
Understanding the Ladder Problem

  • A ladder of length l is leaning against a wall
  • The bottom of the ladder is distance d from the wall
  • Use the sliders to adjust the ladder length and distance from wall
  • Watch how the height h on the wall changes as you move the sliders
  • The visualization shows the right triangle formed by the ladder, wall, and ground

The Pythagorean Theorem

This problem demonstrates the Pythagorean theorem: h² + d² = l²

Where:

  • h = height on the wall (blue)
  • d = distance from wall (yellow/gold)
  • l = ladder length (purple)

problem2Info.heading: The Final Challenge
problem2Info.body:
How to Play

  • Find the distance between the Harbor (blue point) and Market (red point) on the coordinate grid
  • Complete three steps in order: horizontal distance (Δx), vertical distance (Δy), and direct distance
  • Visual guides appear to help you understand each measurement
  • Enter your answer and click the check button to verify
  • Watch the triangle components appear as you progress through each step

What You're Learning

This challenge applies the Pythagorean theorem to coordinate geometry:

  • Δx = horizontal distance between points (pink)
  • Δy = vertical distance between points (purple)
  • Direct distance = hypotenuse using √(Δx² + Δy²) (green)

You'll see how the theorem works with real coordinate points!

S10_D0_FX_C9.deltaXCorrect: Correct! Now find the vertical distance (Δy).
S10_D0_FX_C9.deltaYCorrect: Excellent! Now calculate the direct distance using a² + b² = c².
S10_D0_FX_C9.hypotenuseCorrect: Perfect! You have completed the challenge.

S10_D0_FX_C9.deltaYIncorrect: Not quite. Count the vertical grid squares between the points.
S10_D0_FX_C9.hypotenuseIncorrect: That's not it. Remember: c = √(a² + b²)

S10.S10_D1_FX_C1: Now you must use the theorem to help people in Croton. A worker has a 15-foot ladder and places the bottom 9 feet from the wall. How high will it reach? Remember, the ladder forms the hypotenuse of a right triangle.
S10.S10_D2_FX_C1: Perfect! You found that 9² + 12² = 15², so the ladder reaches 12 feet high. This is another Pythagorean triple: 9-12-15.
S10.S10_D3_FX_C1: Next, I need to travel from the Harbor at coordinate (2, 1) to the Market at (10, 7). What is the shortest distance? Think of this as a right triangle on the coordinate grid. Count the horizontal change and vertical change, then use the theorem.
S10.S10_D4_FX_C1: Brilliant! The horizontal leg is 8 units, the vertical leg is 6 units, and 8² + 6² = 10². The shortest distance is 10 units. You've mastered the ancient art of using mathematics to solve real problems!

quest_completion.subheading: You have mastered the secrets of Pythagoras!
quest_completion.content:
You successfully completed the Pythagoras Quest: The Apprentice of Croton Quest.

  • You discovered the harmony in musical ratios
  • You explored number shapes with ancient pebbles
  • You proved the Pythagorean theorem
  • You solved real-world problems using mathematics
  • You joined the ranks of the Mathematikoi

You now carry forward the ancient wisdom that mathematics is the hidden language of the universe.

monochord.definition: A monochord is a simple musical instrument with one string used to demonstrate mathematical ratios in harmony and sound. Ancient Greek philosophers used it to discover the mathematical relationships that create beautiful music.

mathematikoi.definition: The Mathematikoi were the inner circle of Pythagoras's students who learned the deepest mathematical and philosophical secrets. They were the keepers of mathematical wisdom in ancient Greece.

tetractys.definition: The Tetractys is a sacred triangular arrangement of ten dots (1+2+3+4=10) that represents the harmony of mathematical relationships. It contains the musical ratios and represents the building blocks of the universe: the point, the line, the plane, and the solid.

right-triangle.definition: A right triangle is a triangle with one 90-degree angle, where the Pythagorean theorem applies. Ancient builders used right triangles to create perfect corners in their constructions.

right-triangles.definition: A right triangle is a triangle with one 90-degree angle, where the Pythagorean theorem applies. Ancient builders used right triangles to create perfect corners in their constructions.

hypotenuse.definition: The hypotenuse is the longest side of a right triangle, opposite to the right angle. It is the side represented by 'c' in the Pythagorean theorem equation a²+b²=c².

figurate-numbers.definition: Figurate numbers are numbers that can be represented by regular geometric shapes, such as triangular numbers or square numbers. Ancient Greek mathematicians discovered these patterns using pebbles arranged in geometric forms.

pythagorean-theorem.definition: The Pythagorean theorem is the mathematical principle that in a right triangle, a²+b²=c², where c is the hypotenuse and a and b are the other two sides. This universal law was discovered by Pythagoras and is still used today in construction, navigation, and many other fields.
